entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The stinac has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the stinac moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the stinac can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack:
entries: The Stinac makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claw.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Frightful Roar {@recharge 5}
entries: The Stinac emits a terrifying roar. Each creature of the Stinac's choice within 30 feet of it that can hear the roar must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Zombie Giant makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult hill giants like to hurl themselves bodily at smaller foes and crush them beneath their bulk. This ability is represented by the following action option.

entries.name: Squash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or Smaller creature. {@h}26 ({@damage 6d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, the giant lands {@condition prone} in the target's space, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition prone}. The grapple ends early if the giant stands up.

Hill giants are selfish, dimwitted brutes that hunt, forage, and raid in constant search of food. They blunder through hills and forests devouring what they can, bullying smaller creatures into feeding them. Their laziness and dullness would long ago have spelled their end if not for their formidable size and strength.

entries.name: Primitive
entries: Hill giants dwell in hills and mountain valleys across the world, congregating in steadings built of rough timber or in clusters of well-defended mud-and-wattle huts. Their skins are tan from lives spent lumbering up and down the hilly slopes and dozing beneath the sun. Their weapons are uprooted trees and rocks pulled from the earth. The sweat of their bodies adds to the reek of the crude animal skins they wear, poorly stitched together with hair and leather thongs.

entries.name: Bigger Means Better
entries: In a hill giant's world, humanoids and animals are easy prey that can be hunted with impunity. Creatures such as dragons and other giants are tough adversaries. Hill giants equate size with power.

Hill giants don't realize they follow an ordning. They know only that other giants are larger and stronger than they are, which means they are to be obeyed. A hill giant tribe's chief is usually the tallest and fattest giant that can still move about. Only on rare occasion does a hill giant with more brains than bulk use its cunning to gain the favor of giants of higher status, cleverly subverting the social order.

entries.name: Voracious Eaters
entries: With nothing else to occupy them, hill giants eat as often as possible. A hill giant hunts and forages alone or with a dire wolf companion, so as to not have to share with other tribe members. The giant eats anything that isn't obviously deadly, such as creatures known to be poisonous. Rotten meat is fair game, though, as are decaying plants and even mud.

Farmers fear and loathe hill giants. Where a predator such as an ankheg might burrow through fields and consume a cow or two before being driven off, a hill giant will consume a whole herd of cattle before moving on to sheep, goats, and chickens, then tearing into fruits, vegetables, and grain. If a farm family is at hand, the giant might snack on them too.

entries.name: Stupid and Deadly
entries: The hill giants' ability to digest nearly anything has allowed them to survive for eons as savages, eating and breeding in the hills like animals. They have never needed to adapt and change, so their minds and emotions remain simple and undeveloped.

With no culture of their own, hill giants ape the traditions of creatures they manage to observe for a time before eating them. They don't think about their own size and strength, however. Tribes of hill giants attempting to imitate elves have been known to topple entire forests by trying to live in trees. Others attempting to take over humanoid towns or villages get only as far as the doors and windows of a building, taking out its walls and roof as they attempt to enter.

In conversation, hill giants are blunt and direct, and they have little concept of deception. A hill giant might be fooled into running from another giant if a number of villagers cover themselves in blankets and stand on one another's shoulders holding a giant-painted pumpkin head. Reasoning with a hill giant is futile, although clever creatures can sometimes encourage a giant to take actions that benefit them.

entries.name: Raging Bullies
entries: A hill giant that feels as though it has been deceived, insulted, or made into a fool vents its terrible wrath on anything it encounters. Even after smashing those who offended it into pulp, the giant rampages until its rage abates, it notices something more interesting, or it grows hungry.

If a hill giant proclaims itself king over a territory where other humanoids live, it rules strictly by terror and tyranny. Its decisions shift with its mood, and if it forgets the title it bestowed upon itself, it might eat its subjects on a whim.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.
Boulders assailed our walls and cast them down, leavin' gaps through which the giants strode, weapons in hand.
entries.by: Captain Dwern Addlestone's partial account of the Siege of Sterngate

entries: And here is where Angerroth the barbarian fell against the giant horde. His bones are under that boulder over there.
entries.by: Elder Zelane of Istivin, recounting the Giant Wars

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie giant to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie giant drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Skeleton Giant makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

variant.name: New Giant Options
entries: Some adult hill giants like to hurl themselves bodily at smaller foes and crush them beneath their bulk. This ability is represented by the following action option.

entries.name: Squash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or Smaller creature. {@h}26 ({@damage 6d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, the giant lands {@condition prone} in the target's space, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition prone}. The grapple ends early if the giant stands up.

Hill giants are selfish, dimwitted brutes that hunt, forage, and raid in constant search of food. They blunder through hills and forests devouring what they can, bullying smaller creatures into feeding them. Their laziness and dullness would long ago have spelled their end if not for their formidable size and strength.

entries.name: Primitive
entries: Hill giants dwell in hills and mountain valleys across the world, congregating in steadings built of rough timber or in clusters of well-defended mud-and-wattle huts. Their skins are tan from lives spent lumbering up and down the hilly slopes and dozing beneath the sun. Their weapons are uprooted trees and rocks pulled from the earth. The sweat of their bodies adds to the reek of the crude animal skins they wear, poorly stitched together with hair and leather thongs.

entries.name: Bigger Means Better
entries: In a hill giant's world, humanoids and animals are easy prey that can be hunted with impunity. Creatures such as dragons and other giants are tough adversaries. Hill giants equate size with power.

Hill giants don't realize they follow an ordning. They know only that other giants are larger and stronger than they are, which means they are to be obeyed. A hill giant tribe's chief is usually the tallest and fattest giant that can still move about. Only on rare occasion does a hill giant with more brains than bulk use its cunning to gain the favor of giants of higher status, cleverly subverting the social order.

entries.name: Voracious Eaters
entries: With nothing else to occupy them, hill giants eat as often as possible. A hill giant hunts and forages alone or with a dire wolf companion, so as to not have to share with other tribe members. The giant eats anything that isn't obviously deadly, such as creatures known to be poisonous. Rotten meat is fair game, though, as are decaying plants and even mud.

Farmers fear and loathe hill giants. Where a predator such as an ankheg might burrow through fields and consume a cow or two before being driven off, a hill giant will consume a whole herd of cattle before moving on to sheep, goats, and chickens, then tearing into fruits, vegetables, and grain. If a farm family is at hand, the giant might snack on them too.

entries.name: Stupid and Deadly
entries: The hill giants' ability to digest nearly anything has allowed them to survive for eons as savages, eating and breeding in the hills like animals. They have never needed to adapt and change, so their minds and emotions remain simple and undeveloped.

With no culture of their own, hill giants ape the traditions of creatures they manage to observe for a time before eating them. They don't think about their own size and strength, however. Tribes of hill giants attempting to imitate elves have been known to topple entire forests by trying to live in trees. Others attempting to take over humanoid towns or villages get only as far as the doors and windows of a building, taking out its walls and roof as they attempt to enter.

In conversation, hill giants are blunt and direct, and they have little concept of deception. A hill giant might be fooled into running from another giant if a number of villagers cover themselves in blankets and stand on one another's shoulders holding a giant-painted pumpkin head. Reasoning with a hill giant is futile, although clever creatures can sometimes encourage a giant to take actions that benefit them.

entries.name: Raging Bullies
entries: A hill giant that feels as though it has been deceived, insulted, or made into a fool vents its terrible wrath on anything it encounters. Even after smashing those who offended it into pulp, the giant rampages until its rage abates, it notices something more interesting, or it grows hungry.

If a hill giant proclaims itself king over a territory where other humanoids live, it rules strictly by terror and tyranny. Its decisions shift with its mood, and if it forgets the title it bestowed upon itself, it might eat its subjects on a whim.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.
Boulders assailed our walls and cast them down, leavin' gaps through which the giants strode, weapons in hand.
entries.by: Captain Dwern Addlestone's partial account of the Siege of Sterngate

entries: And here is where Angerroth the barbarian fell against the giant horde. His bones are under that boulder over there.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The winged guard has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the winged guard hits with it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Winged Guard makes two attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft. or range 20/60ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus ({@damage 1d10}) radiant damage.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d4 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength Saving Throw or be knocked Prone

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The Winged Guard Adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. TO do so, the winged Guard must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Scriber of Lies is a 20th-level spellcaster. Their Spellcasting Ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 23}, {@hit 15} to hit with spell attacks). The Scriber of Lies has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: {@b Equipment: Headband of Dual Consciousness}. The wearer of this headband gains the ability to concentrate on two spells simultaneously. Whenever they take damage, they need to make concentration checks as normal, but failing this check results in losing both spells.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The scriber of lies has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Trained Thinker
entries: The Scriber of Lies has advantage on Constitution saving throws that you make to maintain your {@status concentration} on a spell when you take damage.

action.name: Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) Fire damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Kaleehn is a 20th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 22}, {@hit 17} to hit with spell attacks). He has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Kaleehn has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If Kaleehn fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Equipment
entries: Kaleehn has a pair of Winged boots and an activated Chain of Silence (1 minute active meaning no Verbal components required)

action.name: Metal Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Counterspell
entries: Kaleehn has 4 free castings of 3rd level counterspell from the rings he is carrying

legendary.name: Cast spell (Costs 1 Action)
entries: Kaleehn casts a spell of 3rd level or lower.

trait.name: Telepathic Bond
entries: The fiend ignores the range restriction on its telepathy when communicating with a creature it has {@condition charmed}. The two don't even need to be on the same plane of existence.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The fiend can use its action to polymorph into a Small, Medium or Large humanoid, or back into its true form. Without wings, the fiend loses its flying speed. Other than its size and speed, its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Greater Succubus makes 3 claw attacks

action.name: Claw (Fiend Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage.

action.name: Charm
entries: One creature the fiend can see within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed} for 1 day. The {@condition charmed} target obeys the fiend's verbal or telepathic commands. If the target suffers any harm or receives a suicidal command, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success. If the target successfully saves against the effect, or if the effect on it ends, the target is immune to this fiend's Charm for the next 24 hours.
The fiend can have only one target {@condition charmed} at a time. If it charms another, the effect on the previous target ends.

action.name: Draining Kiss
entries: The fiend kisses a creature {@condition charmed} by it or a willing creature. The target must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw against this magic, taking 62 ({@damage 10d10 + 7}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: The fiend magically enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa.

Succubi and incubi inhabit all of the Lower Planes, and the lascivious dark-winged fiends can be found in service to devils, demons, night hags, rakshasas, and yugoloths. Asmodeus, ruler of the Nine Hells, uses these fiends to tempt mortals to perform evil acts. The demon lord Graz'zt keeps succubi and incubi as advisers and consorts.

Though legend speaks of them separately, any succubus can become an incubus, and vice versa. Most of these fiends do have a preference for one form or the other. Mortals only rarely see a succubus or incubus in its true form, however, for the fiend typically begins its corruption in veiled, insidious ways.

entries.name: Beautiful Corrupters
entries: A succubus or incubus first appears in ethereal form, passing through walls like a ghost to lurk next to a mortal's bedside and whisper forbidden pleasures. Sleeping victims are tempted to give in to their darkest desires, indulge in taboos, and feed forbidden appetites. As the fiend fills the victim's dreams with debauched images, the victim becomes more susceptible to temptation in everyday life.

Inevitably, the fiend enters the mortal realm in tempting form to directly influence a creature's actions. Appearing in the guise of a humanoid who has previously appeared only in the victim's dreams, the succubus or incubus seduces or befriends its victim, indulging all its desires so that it performs evil acts of its own free will.

A mortal bequeaths its soul to the fiend not by formal pledge or contract. Instead, when a succubus or incubus has corrupted a creature completely-some say by causing the victim to commit the three betrayals of thought, word, and deed-the victim's soul belongs to the fiend. The more virtuous the fiend's prey, the longer the corruption takes, but the more rewarding the downfall. After successfully corrupting a victim, the succubus or incubus kills it, and the tainted soul descends into the Lower Planes.

The succubus or incubus resorts to charming a victim magically only when necessary, usually as a form of self-defense. A {@condition charmed} creature isn't responsible for its actions, so forcing it to behave against its will won't bring the fiend closer to the ultimate prize: the victim's soul.

entries.name: Deadly Kiss
entries: The kiss of a succubus or incubus is an echo of the emptiness that is the fiend's longing for a corrupted soul. Likewise, the recipient of the fiend's kiss gains no satisfaction from it, experiencing only pain and the profound emptiness that the fiend imparts. The kiss is nothing short of an attack, usually delivered as a final farewell before the fiend escapes.

entries.name: Fiendish Offspring
entries: Succubi and incubi can reproduce with one another to spawn more of their kind. Less commonly, a succubus or incubus reproduces with a humanoid. From this unholy union, a {@creature cambion} child is conceived. Invariably, the fiendish offspring is as wicked as its fiendish parent.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Greater Succubus casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (Spell Save {@dc 22})

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The student of the spellbreaker arts has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the student of the spellbreaker arts hits with it.

trait.name: Indomitable (2/Day).
entries: The student of the spellbreaker rerolls a failed saving throw.

trait.name: Mage Slayer
entries: When the student of the spellbreaker arts damage a creature that is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell, that creature has disadvantage on the saving throw it makes to maintain its {@status concentration}.

reaction.name: Striker the Caster
entries: When a creature within 20 feet of the student of the spellbreaker arts casts a spell, they can use their reaction to make a melee weapon attack against that creature.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +8} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

bonus.name: Bracelet of Misty Step (3/Day)
entries: The student of the spellbreaker arts can as a bonus action {@spell misty step} using its Bracelet of Misty Step.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Perran is an 12th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (Spell save {@dc 18}, +10 to hit with spell attacks). He has the following paladin spells prepared:
Perran can cast Chain Lightning, Lightning Bolt and Thunder Step once a day from his sword Tempest Heir.

trait.name: Aura of Protection
entries: Perran surrounds himself with an Aura of Protection that adds a +5 to his own saving throw as well as any friendly creatures within 10ft. Additionally individuals affected by the aura cannot be {@condition charmed}. (Included)

trait.name: Divine Smite
entries: When Perran hits a creature with a melee weapon attack, he can expend a spell slot to deal radiant damage.
The extra damage is {@dice 2d8} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@dice 1d8} for each spell level higher than 1st.
Additionally whenever Perran hits a creature with a melee weapon, the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d8} radiant damage. (Included)

trait.name: Equipment
entries: Perran has the following items on his person at all times : Tempest Heir, Dragonslayer Pike, Cursed Mirror, Guardian Emblem and most important SOLS aka "Secata.Ordanance.Light.Strider 214th Battalion | BlackBox"

action.name: Extra Attack
entries: Perran can attack twice per turn with his weapons.

action.name: Tempest Heir +3
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 1d8 + 10}) slashing damage plus {@damage 1d12} lightning damage plus {@damage 1d8} radiant damage.

action.name: Energy Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) radiant damage plus {@damage 1d8} radiant damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Geisha is a 13th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 21}, +13 to hit with spell attacks). Geisha has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Equipment
entries: Geisha has the following items on her person at all times : Reaper's Bracelet, Reactive Field Emitter, Mask of Awareness and Frostclaw Pin.

action.name: Vampiric Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage. Geisha regains an amount of hit points equal to the damage dealt. If Geisha has less than half of her hit points, she has advantage on any attack roll she makes with her bite.
When she damages a creature with her Vampiric Bite, she gains a bonus to the next attack roll or ability check she makes equal to the piercing damage dealt.

bonus.name: Telekinetic Shove/Pull
entries: 60 ft. range, one target. Geisha attempts to either shove or pull a creature telekinetically. The target makes a Strength saving throw ({@dc 21}). On a failure, the target is moved 5 feet closer or further away from Geisha.

trait.name: Equipment
entries: Berny has the following items on his person at all times : Amulet of Guardian, Misty Mug, Tattoo of Blur and Spell Refueling Ring

trait.name: Scrubbin Time
entries: Berny commands {@creature Scrub Guardian|ToL}

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Berny is a 13th-level Artificer. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). He has the following artificer spells prepared:

action.name: Anti Matter Rifle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 300/900 ft., one target. {@h}60 ({@damage 10d10 + 5}) necrotic damage. If the target is reduced to 0 hit points, they do not roll death saves, they are instead affected by the {@spell disintegrate} spell as they are turned to dust.

monster.name: Scrub Guardian
languages: understands commands given in any language but can't speak

trait.name: Bound
entries: Scrub Guardian is magically bound to an amulet that {@creature Benard "Berny" Groaucer|ToL} carries. As long as Scrub guardian and Berny are on the same plane of existence, Berny can telepathically call the guardian to travel to it, and Scrub guardian knows the distance and direction to the amulet. If Scrub guardian is within 60 feet of Berny, half of any damage Berny takes (rounded up) is transferred to Scrub guardian.

trait.name: Spell Storing
entries: Berny who wears Scrub Guardian's amulet can cause Scrub guardian to store on spell of 4th level or lower. To do so, Berny must cast the spell on Scrub guardian. The spell has no effect but is stored within scrub guardian. When commanded to do so by Berny or when a situation arises that was predefined by Berny, Scrub guardian casts the stored spell with any parameters set by Berny, requiring no components. When the spell is cast or a new spell is stored, any previously stored spell is lost.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Scrub guardian makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Lightning Launcher {@recharge 5}
entries: Scrub Guardian fires his lightning Launcher in a 60-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Poison Smoke Screen (1/Day)
entries: Scrub Guardian pierces himself with his Poison stinger, as his poison immunity disperses the poison out through his scales, as a poison cloud. Any creature within 10ft of Scrub Guardian, must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 12d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fear Ray Stalk {@recharge}
entries: Scrub Guardian points his Fear Ray from a Beholder and targets a creature within 120ft.

The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Shield
entries: When a creature makes an attack against Berny, Scrub guardian grants a +2 bonus to Berny's AC if Scrub guardian is within 5 feet of Berny.

monster.name: Marauder v1

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Fire Absorption
entries: Whenever the golem is subjected to fire damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the fire damage dealt.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes three attacks.

action.name: Scorching Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) Fire damage.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage.

The Marauder 1.0 is a menacing construct mounted on wheels, its large upper body dominated by two scorching cannons on each side. In its torso, a mechanical-looking red eye glows ominously. Swift and deadly, it's a formidable force on the battlefield, its purpose clear—to annihilate anything in its path.

monster.name: Marauder v2

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Metallic Grasp
entries: The Marauder can switch out a claw attack to attempt to grapple one creature within 15 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 24}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the Marauder can't use this claw against other targets.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes Three attacks. Two with its claws and one with its stinger, or it can make one claw attack and Fire Beam

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) slashing damage

action.name: Stinger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}38 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fire Beam {@recharge 5}
entries: The Marauder unleashes a powerful beam of fire from the orb atop its body. Each creature in a 120-foot line that is 10 feet wide must make a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 70 ({@damage 20d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

fluff.name: Iron Golem
entries: The mightiest of the golems, the iron golem is a massive, towering giant wrought of heavy metal. An iron golem's shape can be worked into any form, though most are fashioned to look like giant suits of armor. Its fist can destroy creatures with a single blow, and its clanging steps shake the earth beneath its feet. Iron golems wield enormous blades to extend their reach, and all can belch clouds of deadly poison.

An iron golem's body is smelted with rare tinctures and admixtures. Though other golems bear weaknesses inherent in their materials or the power of the elemental spirit bound within them, iron golems were designed to be nearly invulnerable. Their iron bodies imprison the spirits that drive them, and are susceptible only to weapons imbued with magic or the strength of adamantine.

Beyond the unopenable doors lay a grand hall ending before a towering stone throne, upon which sat an iron statue taller and wider than two men. In one  and it clutched an iron sword, in the other, a feather whip. We should have turned back then.
entries.from: chronicling his party's harrowing exploits in the dungeons below Maure Castle

entries.name: Golems
entries: Golems are made from humble materials-clay, flesh and bones, iron, or stone-but they possess astonishing power and durability. A golem has no ambitions, needs no sustenance, feels no pain, and knows no remorse. An unstoppable juggernaut, it exists to follow its creator's orders, and it protects or attacks as that creator demands.
To create a golem, one requires a {@item manual of golems}. The comprehensive illustrations and instructions in a manual detail the process for creating a golem of a particular type.

entries.name: Elemental Spirit in Material Form
entries: The construction of a golem begins with the building of its body, requiring great command of the craft of sculpting, stonecutting, ironworking, or surgery. Sometimes a golem's creator is the master of the art, but often the individual who desires a golem must enlist master artisans to do the work.

After constructing the body from clay, flesh, iron, or stone, the golem's creator infuses it with a spirit from the Elemental Plane of Earth. This tiny spark of life has no memory, personality, or history. It is simply the impetus to move and obey. This process binds the spirit to the artificial body and subjects it to the will of the golem's creator.
A golem can be created with a special amulet or other item that allows the possessor of the item to control the golem. Golems whose creators are long dead can thus be harnessed to serve a new master.
A golem can't think or act for itself. Though it understands its commands perfectly, it has no grasp of language beyond that understanding, and can't be reasoned with or tricked with words.

entries.name: Ageless Guardians
entries: Golems can guard sacred sites, tombs, and treasure vaults long after the deaths of their creators, carrying out their appointed tasks for all eternity while brushing off physical damage and ignoring all but the most potent spells.

entries.name: Blind Obedience
entries: When its creator or possessor is on hand to command it, a golem performs flawlessly. If the golem is left without instructions or is {@condition incapacitated}, it continues to follow its last orders to the best of its ability. When it can't fulfill its orders, a golem might react violently-or stand and do nothing. A golem that has been given conflicting orders sometimes alternates between them.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: A golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

reaction.name: Reactive Pulse {@recharge 5}
entries: When the Marauder takes damage from a creature within 30 feet of it, it can use its reaction to unleash a wave of kinetic energy from the orb atop its body. Each creature within 80 feet of the Marauder must succeed on a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw or be pushed back 20 feet and knocked {@condition prone}, taking 49 ({@damage 14d6}) force damage. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

resist.preNote: Resistant to all, both non magical and magical

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The karlaan has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The karlaan's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Brutel
entries: A melee weapon deals three extra die of its damage when karlaan hits with it.

trait.name: Blood Sacrifice
entries: Whenever Karlaan makes a saving throw, he can choose to take 50 psychic damage to succeed on the saving throw instead. (Damage already doubled)

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the karlaan can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Karlaan makes three attacks with his Greataxe. He can choose to swap out either a reckless leap or frightful presence for a Greataxe attack.

action.name: Greataxe +3
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Reckless Leap
entries: Karlaan Leaps into the air and moves 60ft in the air. Afterwards he smashes into the ground sending the ground churning in a 20ft circle around where he landed. Each creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 8d8} bludgeoning damage and fall {@condition prone}, or half ads much damage on a success and not fall {@condition prone}

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each hostile creature within 120 feet of Karlaan must succeed on a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute.
A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Arcane Deflection

trait.name: Spellfocus

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The steel wolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The steel wolf has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Steel Wolf makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. Alternatively, it can make one bite attack and use its Petrifying Breath.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Petrifying Breath (Recharge 5–6):
entries: The Steel Wolf exhales petrifying gas in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the creature is freed by the greater restoration spell or other magic.

The Steel Wolf is thought to have deviated from a dire wolf while wandering the depths of Lumeeria's underground maze, Kudan's Maze. Here, the ominous energies that persist to this day caused a dire wolf to transform into a Steel Wolf. Steel Wolves have a thick outer hide with edges as sharp as steel, making them formidable predators and guardians of the dark. Their bodies have adapted to the harsh environment, gaining resilience and abilities that allow them to thrive in the underground labyrinths of Lumeeria.

vulnerable.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from Silvered weapons

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the duke fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The duke has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The duke has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The duke's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Pounce (The Duke)
entries: If the duke moves at least 15 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the duke can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Shapechanger (Werewolf)
entries: The duke can use its action to polymorph into a wolf-humanoid hybrid or into a wolf, or back into its true form, which is humanoid. Its statistics, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Duke makes 5 attacks. He can only do one bite attack per turn. He can forego two attacks to use Howl of Terror

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}41 ({@damage 5d12 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Howl of Terror
entries: The Duke emits a terrifying howl. Each creature of the Duke's choice within 120 feet and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 23} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the Duke is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success.

legendary.name: Duke - Move & Attack (1)
entries: The Duke moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks, and does a Bite attack against a target within range

legendary.name: Torodel - Cast spell (2)
entries: Torodel Cast's a spell of 5th level or lower.

legendary.name: Torodel - Paralyzing Touch (1)
entries: Torodel uses his Paralyzing Touch

legendary.name: Torodel and Duke - Claw and Despair (2)
entries: Torodel and the Duke both do something, Torodel uses his Darkest Despair on a target within range, while Duke uses two claw attacks on a target within range.

monster.name: Lich - Torodel Yelra
languages: Common plus up to five other languages

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lich is an 20th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 24}, {@hit 16} to hit with spell attacks). The lich has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: Torodel Yelra has the Boon of High Magic

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the lich fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If it has a phylactery, a destroyed lich gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the phylactery.

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The lich has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The lich - torodel yelra has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Paralyzing Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Liches are the remains of great wizards who embrace undeath as a means of preserving themselves. They further their own power at any cost, having no interest in the affairs of the living except where those affairs interfere with their own. Scheming and insane, they hunger for long-forgotten knowledge and the most terrible secrets. Because the shadow of death doesn't hang over them, they can conceive plans that take years, decades, or centuries to come to fruition.

A lich is a gaunt and skeletal humanoid with withered flesh stretched tight across its bones. Its eyes succumbed to decay long ago, but points of light burn in its empty sockets. It is often garbed in the moldering remains of fine clothing and jewelry worn and dulled by the passage of time.

entries.name: Secrets of Undeath
entries: No wizard takes up the path to lichdom on a whim, and the process of becoming a lich is a well-guarded secret. Wizards that seek lichdom must make bargains with fiends, evil gods, or other foul entities. Many turn to Orcus, Demon Prince of Undeath, whose power has created countless liches. However, those that control the power of lichdom always demand fealty and service for their knowledge.

A lich is created by an arcane ritual that traps the wizard's soul within a phylactery. Doing so binds the soul to the mortal world, preventing it from traveling to the Outer Planes after death. A phylactery is traditionally an amulet in the shape of a small box, but it can take the form of any item possessing an interior space into which arcane sigils of naming, binding, immortality, and dark magic are scribed in silver.

With its phylactery prepared, the future lich drinks a potion of transformation-a vile concoction of poison mixed with the blood of a sentient creature whose soul is sacrificed to the phylactery. The wizard falls dead, then rises as a lich as its soul is drawn into the phylactery, where it forever remains.

entries.name: Soul Sacrifices
entries: A lich must periodically feed souls to its phylactery to sustain the magic preserving its body and consciousness. It does this using the {@spell imprisonment} spell. Instead of choosing one of the normal options of the spell, the lich uses the spell to magically trap the target's body and soul inside its phylactery. The phylactery must be on the same plane as the lich for the spell to work. A lich's phylactery can hold only one creature at a time, and a {@spell dispel magic} cast as a 9th-level spell upon the phylactery releases any creature imprisoned within it. A creature imprisoned in the phylactery for 24 hours is consumed and destroyed utterly, whereupon nothing short of divine intervention can restore it to life.
A lich that fails or forgets to maintain its body with sacrificed souls begins to physically fall apart, and might eventually become a demilich.

entries.name: Death and Restoration
entries: When a lich's body is broken by accident or assault, the will and mind of the lich drains from it, leaving only a lifeless corpse behind. Within days, a new body reforms next to the lich's phylactery, coalescing out of glowing smoke that issues from the device. Because the destruction of its phylactery means the possibility of eternal death, a lich usually keeps its phylactery in a hidden, well-guarded location.

Destroying a lich's phylactery is no easy task and often requires a special ritual, item, or weapon. Every phylactery is unique, and discovering the key to its destruction can be a quest in and of itself.

entries.name: Lonely Existence
entries: From time to time, a lich might be stirred from its single-minded pursuit of power to take an interest in the world around it, most often when some great event reminds it of the life it once led. It otherwise lives in isolation, engaging only with those creatures whose service helps secure its lair.
Few liches call themselves by their former names, instead adopting monikers such as the Black Hand or the Forgotten King.

entries.name: Magic Collectors
entries: Liches collect spells and magic items. In addition to its spell repertoire, a lich has ready access to potions, scrolls, libraries of spellbooks, one or more wands, and perhaps a staff or two. It has no qualms about putting these treasures to use whenever its lair comes under attack.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A lich doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: A Lich's Lair
entries: A lich often haunts the abode it favored in life, such as a lonely tower, a haunted ruin, or an academy of black magic. Alternatively, some liches construct secret tombs filled with powerful guardians and traps. Everything about a lich's lair reflects its keen mind and wicked cunning, including the magic and mundane traps that secure it. Undead, constructs, and bound demons lurk in shadowy recesses, emerging to destroy those who dare to disturb the lich's work.
A lich encountered in its lair has a challenge rating of 22 (41,000 XP).

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the lich can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects; the lich can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: The lich rolls a {@dice d8} and regains a spell slot of that level or lower. If it has no spent spell slots of that level or lower, nothing happens.

The lich targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. A crackling cord of negative energy tethers the lich to the target. Whenever the lich takes damage, the target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the lich takes half the damage (rounded down), and the target takes the remaining damage. This tether lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round or until the lich or the target is no longer in the lich's lair.

The lich calls forth the spirits of creatures that died in its lair. These apparitions materialize and attack one creature that the lich can see within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 52 ({@damage 15d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a success. The apparitions then disappear.

bonus.name: Darkest Despair
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 16} to hit, unlimited range, one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) necrotic damage. The target has disadvantage on the next saving throw they take within 1 minute of being hit by Darkest Despair.

legendary.name: Duke - Move & Attack (1)
entries: The Duke moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks, and does a Bite attack against a target within range

legendary.name: Torodel - Cast spell (2)
entries: Torodel Cast's a spell of 5th level or lower.

legendary.name: Torodel - Paralyzing Touch (1)
entries: Torodel uses his Paralyzing Touch

legendary.name: Torodel and Duke - Claw and Despair (2)
entries: Torodel and the Duke both do something, Torodel uses his Darkest Despair on a target within range, while Duke uses two claw attacks on a target within range.

trait.name: Lightning Reflexes
entries: The Tempest Sword Practitioner has advantage on initiative rolls.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the Tempest Sword Practitioner is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The practitioner's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Tempest Sword Practitioner makes three attacks: Three Tempest Blade attacks or two Tempest Blade attacks and Wind Blade.

action.name: Tempest Blade - Harkin Sword +1
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) slashing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} as wind pushes the target to the ground.

action.name: Wind Blade {@recharge 5}
entries: The Tempest Sword Practitioner can shoot out from its position a 10-foot-wide wind blade that damages all in a 60-foot line. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

bonus.name: Wind Dash
entries: The Tempest Sword Practitioner can move up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks. If it moves at least 20 feet in a straight line toward a target, it can make one melee weapon attack against that target as part of this bonus action.

reaction.name: Tempest Parry
entries: The Tempest Sword Practitioner adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. It can then make one melee weapon attack against the attacker

monster.name: Blood Count

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Count's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 26}, +18 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Counts Wrath
entries: if the Count would be reduced to 0 hit points, his current hit point total instead resets to 1500 hit points.
Additionally, the Count can now use the options in the Mythic Actions section for 1 hour.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The Blood Count regains 50 hit points at the start of its turn. If the Blood Count takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The Blood Count can at will polymorph into a bat, a wolf, or a cloud of mist, or back into its true form. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The blood count has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The blood count's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The blood count is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Count makes three attacks: one with his bite and two with his claws. Or One with his bite and casts a spell

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d8 + 10}) piercing damage plus 44 ({@damage 8d10}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest, or is affected by the heal, mass heal, or greater restoration spell. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}55 ({@damage 10d8 + 10}) slashing damage.

reactionHeader: The count has 3 Reactions per turn.

reaction.name: Imprisoning Coffin
entries: As a reaction to being attacked, the Blood Count can summon an imprisoning coffin around the attacker. The Blood Count still takes the damage, but the targeted creature is now {@condition restrained}, {@condition blinded}, and {@condition deafened} while trapped within the coffin. The coffin has an AC of 13 and 50 hit points. Any creature can target the coffin. The coffin remains until destroyed or until the Blood Count uses another reaction to summon a new imprisoning coffin.

reaction.name: Spell Copy {@recharge}
entries: When the Count is within 300ft of a creature casting a spell, the blood count can immediately copy the spell and cast it as part of the same reaction.

legendary.name: Legendary Resilience (Costs 3 actions)
entries: The Count ends one spell or harmful effect currently affecting him.

legendary.name: Blooded Neck (Costs 1 Action)
entries: The Count teleports behind one humanoid he can see within 120 feet of him. The Count makes one bite attack towards the humanoid. Additionally if the bite was successful, the targeted humanoid has disadvantage against the Count's Enslaving Charm Ability

legendary.name: Enslaving Charm (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Blood Count targets one humanoid he can see within 30 feet of him. The target must succeed on a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed} by the Blood Count until the Blood Count dies or until he is on a different plane of existence from the target. The {@condition charmed} target is under the Blood Count's control and can't take reactions. The Blood Count can have only one target {@condition charmed} at a time. If the {@condition charmed} target takes any damage, the target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target's saving throw is successful, or if the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Blood Count's Enslaving Charm for the next 24 hours.

legendaryHeader: The blood count can take 5 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The blood count regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.
mythicHeader: If the blood count's mythic trait is active, it can use the options below as legendary actions for 1 hour after using Counts Wrath.

mythic.name: Blood Burst (Costs 1 action)
entries: The Blood Count targets one creature he can see within 120 feet of him. The target must succeed on a {@dc 26} Constitution saving throw or take 35 ({@damage 10d6}) necrotic damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A {@condition poisoned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

mythic.name: Blood Spears (Costs 1 Action)
entries: The Blood Count summons blood-red spears from the ground in a 20-foot radius centered on a point it can see within 120 feet. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 30 ({@damage 6d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

mythic.name: Nightmare's Grasp (Costs 1 action)
entries: The Blood Count targets one creature it can see within 60 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 26} Wisdom saving throw or take 35 ({@damage 10d6}) psychic damage and be {@condition frightened} of the Blood Count for 1 minute. The {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

legendaryGroup.name: Celador Talis
lairActions: When fighting inside his lair, Celador talis can invoke the ambient magic to take lair actions. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Celador talis can take one lair action to cause one of the following effects:
- Celador Talis rolls a d8 and regains a spell slot of that level or lower. If he has no spent spell slots of that level or lower, nothing happens.

- Celador Talis flicks his fingers and out from the walls come green motes of light. Everyone in the room can choose to regain hit points equal to 10d10. Choosing to regain it, in return makes your next 3 saving throws be at disadvantage.
- Celador Talis snaps his finger, and a enchanted rune appears in the ceiling. The hostile creature with the lowest amount of hit points within the lair is targeted by a Power Word Kill spell.

- Celador Talis creates arcane arms to rise form the ground in a 20-foot square that he can see. The arcane arms last until the next initiative count 20. Each creature in that area when the arms appear must succeed on a DC 25 Strength saving throw or be restrained until the arms disappear or until Celador Talis releases them (no action required)
The celador talis can't repeat an effect until they have all been used, and it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row.
regionalEffects: Celador can shoot a ray or beam like spell or his Arcane Burst ability. If it passes through the ray enhancer, it doubles the damage and doubles the range aswell.
Example; Disintegrate spell can be targeted as if the range was doubled if the ray will pass through the enhancer.

Celador can spend a legendary action to trigger the stunning wave, As a wave of purple arcane energy pushes through the center of the lair. Any hostile creature caught in this energy must succeed on a DC 28 Intelligence saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn.

Celador can spend a legendary action to trigger the Cold wave, as a wave of cold energy pushes through the center of the lair both from the top and bottom objects. Any hostile creature caught in this wave must succeed on a DC 28 constitution saving throw, taking 10d6 Cold damage or half as much damage on a successful save.

Celador can move to a golden platform and as a bonus action activate it. This will summon a force field that acts as a Wall of Force. The wall appears where the golden arcane energies exit. The back of the platform being completely open.
When Celador moves off it, it disappears.
Other creatures can attempt to activate the Force Field as a bonus action by succeeding on a Arcana check DC 40.
Celador can touch a pillar and teleport to another pillar in the lair.

legendaryGroup.name: Blood Count
lairActions: When fighting inside its lair, the blood count can invoke the ambient magic to take lair actions. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the blood count can take one lair action to cause one of the following effects:

- The walls of the chamber begin to ooze with dark, viscous bloody tendrils. Each creature within 60 feet of the Blood Count must make a DC 26 Dexterity saving throw or take 22 (4d10) slashing damage from the sharp tendrils of blood that slash those around their count. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage.

- The Blood Count calls forth 1d4 vampire spawn to aid it in battle. These vampire spawn appear in unoccupied spaces within 30 feet of the Blood Count and act immediately after him in the initiative order. They remain for 1 minute or until destroyed, after which they crumble to dust.

- Magical darkness spreads from a point the Blood Count chooses within 60 feet of it, filling a 20-foot-radius sphere until the Blood Count dismisses it as an action, uses this lair action again, or dies. The darkness spreads around corners, and any creature fully within it is blinded. A creature within the area when the darkness appears, or that enters it for the first time on a turn, must make a DC 26 Constitution saving throw, taking 44 (8d10) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that ends its turn in the darkness takes 22 (4d10) necrotic damage.

- The area becomes enveloped in deep shadows, dimming all light and creating an eerie atmosphere. Each creature within 60 feet of the Blood Count must make a DC 26 Constitution saving throw, taking 5d10 necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The Blood Count regains hit points equal to half the total damage dealt by this effect.
The blood count can't repeat an effect until they have all been used, and it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row.
